description: From Middle English squachen, squatchen, from Old French esquacher, escachier, from Vulgar Latin *excoāctiāre, from Latin ex + coāctāre. Probably influenced by Middle English quashen, quassen, from Old French esquasser, escasser (“to crush, shatter, destroy, break”), from Vulgar Latin *exquassare, from Latin ex- + quassare (“to shatter”) (see quash).

entries.meaning: (uncountable) A sport played in a walled court with a soft rubber ball and bats like tennis racquets.
(Britain) A soft drink made from a fruit-based concentrate diluted with water.
examples: Sure. I pour hot squash all over myself and we all have a good chuckle. Everyone except Muggins here.

entries.meaning: A place or a situation where people have limited space to move.
examples: It's a bit of a squash in this small room.

entries.meaning: (biology) A preparation made by placing material on a slide (flat, rectangular piece of glass), covering it and applying pressure.
(obsolete, countable) Something soft and easily crushed; especially, an unripe pod of peas.
(obsolete, countable, derogatory) Something unripe or soft.
(obsolete, countable) A sudden fall of a heavy, soft body; also, a shock of soft bodies.
(slang, professional wrestling) An extremely one-sided, usually short, match.
examples: It was one of the most shocking WWE title matches ever witnessed, and effectively a 20-minute squash match as Brock Lesnar "conquered" his opponent.

verbs.description: squash (third-person singular simple present squashes, present participle squashing, simple past and past participle squashed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To beat or press into pulp or a flat mass; to crush.
(transitive, intransitive) To compress or restrict (oneself) into a small space; to squeeze.
examples: Somehow, she squashed all her books into her backpack, which was now too heavy to carry.
We all managed to squash into Mum's tiny car.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To suppress; to force into submission.

description: Shortening of Narragansett askutasquash (“[a vegetable] eaten green (or raw)”), from askut (“green, raw”) +‎ asquash (“eaten”).

nouns.description: squash (countable and uncountable, plural squash or squashes)

definitionGroups.group: (botany, countable) A plant and its fruit of any of a few species of the genus Cucurbita, or gourd kind.

entries.meaning: Cucurbita maxima, including hubbard squash, great winter squash, buttercup squash, and some varieties of pumpkins.
Cucurbita argyrosperma (syn. Cucurbita mixta), cushaw squash.
Cucurbita moschata, butternut squash, Barbary squash, China squash.
Cucurbita pepo, most pumpkins, acorn squash, summer squash, zucchini.

definitionGroups.group: (botany) Any other similar-looking plant of other genera.

entries.meaning: Lagenaria siceraria (syn. Cucurbita verrucosa), calabash, long-neck squash.
(cooking) The edible or decorative fruit of these plants, or this fruit prepared as a dish.
examples: We ate squash and green beans.
The squash is a four-footed beast, bigger than a cat.
